items.title: The parts of Myanmar the military junta doesn't want you to see

items.summary: Figure skater Anastasia Golubeva becomes an Australian citizen, just six weeks out from the Milano-Cortina Olympics.

items.title: Red and yellow flags can be dangerously confusing. Is it time to change them?

items.title: Today in History, January 3: Steve Waugh secures a last-ball century to complete his perfect day
items.summary: With one ball remaining on day two of the fifth Ashes Test in 2003, Steve Waugh stared down a century and his own cricketing mortality before securing one of the most famous centuries of his storied career.

items.title: Min River takes out overall win in 2025 Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race after protest against BNC
items.summary: Double-handed Min River makes history by becoming the first double-handed yacht to take out the overall win in the Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race and the first to do so with a female skipper.

items.title: Opening the doors to a unique collection, more than seven decades in the making
items.summary: The owner of this sprawling collection of weird, wacky and everyday items hopes it will inspire an appreciation for the past in younger generations.

items.title: Bushfire near Rockingham in Perth's south contained but not controlled as second WA blaze downgraded
items.summary: More than 140 firefighters spend a second night battling an out-of-control blaze near Rockingham, in Perth's southern suburbs, as an emergency warning for a second fire in WA's South West is downgraded.

items.title: Calls for national strategy to tackle apprentice hazing and protect workers’ mental health
items.summary: TV presenter and former builder Barry Du Bois is lobbying Canberra for change.

items.title: Broken Hill gardeners chop down trees in battle with Queensland fruit fly
items.summary: There was no fruit fly to be found in Broken Hill 20 years ago, but now gardeners are facing an uphill battle trying to rid themselves of the pest.

items.title: AI technology gives swimming pool lifeguards an extra set of eyes this summer
items.summary: An AI system used in 120 public pools across Australia analyses swimmers' movements and sends an alert to a lifeguard's smartwatch if it detects someone in trouble.

items.title: What are the new rules in 2026? Here's what's changing from New Year's Day
items.summary: New Year's Day brings a host of new laws, regulations and guidelines into effect. Here's a quick breakdown of some of the changes.

items.title: Calls for tighter regulations after Woodside knowingly shed plastic into ocean
items.summary: Documents reveal one of Australia's biggest oil and gas companies knowingly shed plastic into the ocean for two months before notifying the offshore regulator.

items.title: Record year for Australian beef exports despite Donald Trump's tariffs
items.summary: When Donald Trump enforced a 10 per cent tariff on Australian beef, there were some concerns it would impact trade. But the opposite happened.

items.title: Flocks of tourists dubbed the 'koala paparazzi' putting animals at risk in Byron Bay
items.summary: Large crowds of tourists gather daily at the bottom of trees home to koalas in Byron Bay, leaving the animals stressed and their habitat trampled.

items.title: Perth Scorchers beat Sydney Thunder by 71 runs in Sydney, Ashton Turner stuck on 99 not out
items.summary: Ashton Turner narrowly misses out on a maiden BBL century as he helps launch Perth to a crucial 71-run win over the Sydney Thunder.

items.title: Tatiana Schlossberg, granddaughter of John F Kennedy, dies aged 35
items.summary: Tatiana Schlossberg revealed in an essay published in November that she had a rare form of terminal leukaemia.

items.title: ASX ends 'stressful' year with gold and lithium stocks surging despite Trump's trade war threats
items.summary: Several gold, lithium and other mining stocks have seen their share price double, and even triple, in 2025 as Australia's share market has had a much better than expected year despite tariffs, economic uncertainty and Donald Trump's ongoing unpredictability.

items.title: Mechanic shortage driving Queensland businesses to look overseas for qualified workers
items.summary: The automotive repair industry says it is dealing with a major labour and skills shortage, and some mechanics are looking overseas for workers.

items.title: Cameron Corner celebrates New Year's Eve three times in one night, on three state borders
items.summary: It's more than 1,000km from any capital city, but Cameron Corner, at the junction of the NSW, Queensland and South Australian borders, reckons it has one of the best New Year's Eve parties going around because it is a triple celebration over three time zones.

items.title: For many South Australians, 2025 could be summarised as the year of searching for answers
items.summary: As 2025 draws to a close and we look back at the stories that made headlines, for South Australians the year could be summarised as one where we searched for answers, with little results.

items.title: Robbers steal $52 million from vault of German savings bank
items.summary: According to police, the robbers drilled their way into the underground vault room of the savings bank from a parking garage.

items.title: Denmark becomes first country in world to end letter delivery
items.summary: After 401 years, the Danish postal service has ended letter deliveries as the country fully embraces the digital age.

items.title: What should you do during a violent mass attack?
items.summary: The mass shooting in Bondi and other incidents of mass violence around the world have highlighted that violence can strike anywhere. Here are some expert tips on how to escape, hide, and stay safe.

items.title: Human-operated Tokyo robot venture allows housebound people to work
items.summary: Ory Yoshifuji's Tokyo business employs housebound individuals to operate robots as waitstaff at a cafe and as personal tour guides in the city.

items.title: Sportsbet pressured key watchdog into 'watering down' enforcement announcement
items.summary: Gambling giant Sportsbet pressured the Australian Communications and Media Authority into "watering down" enforcement announcement, the ABC can reveal.

items.title: Crowd-funding business campaigns falter, despite demand for tipple
items.summary: Brewer Richard Jeffares's Victorian company raised about $2.5 million from 993 investors in a matter of days through a method called crowd-sourced funding, also known as equity crowdfunding.

items.title: Kakadu traditional owner says nature has long warned us about rising sea levels
items.summary: In wet season, Jonathan and his family have to drive, boat and drive again if they want to reach town. The remote NT traditional owner says nature has long been warning us about climate change, "but nobody's listening".

items.title: Today in History, December 31: Vladimir Putin rises to power in Russia
items.summary: Vladimir Putin has towered over politics in Russia since ascending to the country's top office, initially as president for eight years, then as prime minister until that pesky thing called the constitution could be altered to allow him to run again.

items.title: Christmas cruise ends in chaos as Coral Adventurer passengers return home
items.summary: About 80 passengers on the Coral Adventurer are flown home after the cruise ship ran aground on a reef off Papua New Guinea.

items.title: South Korea bans bear bile farming with jail for those who breach the law
items.summary: South Korea is one of the few countries that allow farming to extract bile from bears, for traditional medicine or food believed to promote vitality and stamina.

items.summary: Bizzi Lavelle, a Queer Wakka Wakka and Arrernte writer and burlesque dancer known in the scene as Bizzi Body, is reclaiming the hidden legacy of this art-form one tassel twirl at a time.

items.title: Here's what we know about the Coral Adventurer, the cruise ship that ran aground in PNG
items.summary: The Coral Adventurer was carrying 80 tourists into the remote reaches of Papua New Guinea when it came to an abrupt halt on a reef off the Pacific nation's coast.

items.title: Australian laws changed in six important ways in 2025
items.summary: From food delivery to sovereign citizens, Australia's laws underwent some important changes this year.

items.title: Khaleda Zia, Bangladesh's first female prime minister, dead at 80
items.summary: Begum Khaleda Zia was leader of the main opposition Bangladesh Nationalist Party which was seen as the frontrunner to win the next parliamentary election in February.

items.title: NT Environment Protection Authority orders Santos, Inpex licence conditions review
items.summary: The Northern Territory environment regulator will re-examine the licence conditions of major gas facilities in Darwin, after one of its biggest operators admitted to under-reporting potentially toxic emissions at its Ichthys LNG plant on Darwin Harbour.

items.title: Russia's claim Ukraine attacked Putin's home 'doesn't make any sense', experts say
items.summary: A defence analyst tells the ABC an attack on the Russian President's state residence would be "technically" possible but would not make sense strategically for Ukraine.

items.title: Impact of abbreviated Boxing Day Test stretches far beyond the MCG
items.summary: The economic and social impact of the Boxing Day Test reaches far past the pitch and the repercussions of the two-day finish rippled all across Melbourne.

items.title: Gold, silver and palladium prices pull back sharply, worrying some economists
items.summary: The price of palladium — used in electronics — tumbles from recent highs while the prices of other precious metals, including gold and silver, have also sharply declined in recent days.

items.title: Nick Offerman hopes The Pout-Pout Fish delights tough child critics
items.summary: This Australian animation stars an international and local voice cast led by Nick Offerman and Nina Oyama, who can't wait for children to see the film.

items.title: Donald Bradman's baggy green to go under the hammer
items.summary: A baggy green worn by Sir Donald Bradman during the 1947-48 series against India has gone to auction.

items.title: Shoppers spending billions on post-Christmas sales, but small retailers feel forgotten
items.summary: Outlet centres around Australia were bustling on Boxing Day, but just down the road, some small retailers were feeling the sting. It's a trend that could shape the future of the Boxing Day sales.

items.title: Ambulance Victoria reports increase in violence against paramedics over Christmas holiday
items.summary: Ambulance Victoria says paramedics were assaulted, spat on and sexually harassed in a series of serious incidents over the festive period.

items.title: Bushfire near Rockingham closes Mandurah train line, Warnbro station in Perth's south
items.summary: A major train line and Warnbro station are closed as firefighters battle a bushfire burning near Rockingham in Perth's south.

items.title: China hasn't said it wants war in 2026. But it's showing the world it's ready for one
items.summary: While Donald Trump was distracted, China launched its strongest-ever challenge against Taiwan. Beijing is showing it is ready for war.

items.title: SA avoids major bushfire during extreme danger, but home and sheds destroyed
items.summary: South Australia avoided a major bushfire as the state sweltered through a day of extreme danger on Monday, while two structure fires left a damage bill of $1 million.

items.title: It's backed by Maggie Beer and researchers alike, so why don't we eat more offal?
items.summary: Despite becoming less popular in recent years, advocates like Maggie Beer say offal can be a delicacy.

items.title: Tasmania Fire Service confirms bushfire at Stieglitz near St Helens caused by household waste in fire pit
items.summary: A fire that burnt through 1,200 hectares of vegetation and destroyed two houses started in a residential fire pit, Tasmanian authorities say.

items.title: Metal detectorist discovers 1880s Zanzibar coin at Port Macquarie beach
items.summary: Metal detectorist Dale Oldham at first thought he had found a rusted Australian coin, until an online search revealed it was something much older and far more exotic.

items.title: Donald Trump calls for Hamas to disarm after meeting with Benjamin Netanyahu
items.summary: The US president has been hosting Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at his residence in Florida for talks on Gaza and several other issues.

items.title: The importance of preparing for death and creating an end-of-life health care plan
items.summary: Dying in sudden, unexpected circumstances is not something people often consider, but there are plenty of reasons to create an end-of-life plan. So why do so few people have one?

items.title: Daria Kasatkina set for Brisbane International and Australian Open after mental health break
items.summary: Daria Kasatkina is being backed to return from her mental health break and quickly become a fan favourite at her new home grand slam, the Australian Open.

items.title: Deaf people saying no to cochlear implants choosing 'different way of seeing the world'
items.summary: Cochlear implants can be a life-changing tool for people with hearing loss, but some Deaf people argue their use risks compromising their community's identity.

items.title: Charles Darwin University researchers leading the way in fight to protect globally threatened rays
items.summary: Researchers from Charles Darwin University are leading the way in the fight to protect a group of globally threatened fish species, which look like "a shark and ray joined together".

items.title: Donald Trump says US 'knocked out' a 'big facility' in Venezuela
items.summary: A US strike on Venezuelan soil would be the first known land attack in the country since the Trump administration began ratcheting up pressure on its ruling regime, which Donald Trump accuses of "narco-terrorism".

items.title: Noongar elders say WA prescribed burn went ahead despite warnings of cultural heritage sites
items.summary: Elders on WA's south coast say they tried to warn the state government about unregistered cultural sites in the path of a prescribed burn, but the burn went ahead anyway.

items.title: Hiker Stella Thurbon leads herd of goats on trek through Victoria's High Country
items.summary: With bells tinkling, tails flicking, and panniers packed to the brim, adventurer Stella Thurbon has spent 26 days winding through the Victorian High Country with nine goats trotting faithfully behind her.

items.title: Hobart Hurricanes beat Melbourne Renegades thanks to vital cameo from Matthew Wade
items.summary: Matthew Wade's fuss-free cameo helps Hobart chase down the Melbourne Renegades's 163 at Bellerive Oval, lifting the Hurricanes well clear of the pack in second spot.

items.title: South-east Queensland's largest dam is 'full'. What does it mean?
items.summary: South-east Queensland's largest water reservoir provides drinking water and protection from flooding. So, how does it all work?

items.title: Soft plastics recycling is back in Australia. How does it work and where does it go?
items.summary: Australia's first large-scale soft plastics recycling facility is processing huge loads each day, turning waste into a useful raw material.

items.title: Broken Hill records seven earthquakes in 2025 — the most in recorded history
items.summary: It is not unheard of for the ground to shake in Broken Hill, but what is unusual is the number of earthquakes recorded by Geoscience Australia this year.

items.title: Josh Burns on juggling politics and fatherhood and being a Jewish MP
items.summary: In a broad-ranging interview for the Politics Now podcast, the rising Labor star reveals he plans to take extended leave to care for his baby daughter.

items.title: Household battery uptake booms on back of 'game-changer' rebate
items.summary: Battery uptake is booming since the federal government rebate came into effect in July. Here's what you need to know if you are thinking of joining the thousands of Australians adding a battery to their home solar systems.

items.title: What happened when we tested a 'safe' AI mental health chatbot
items.summary: Is it possible to make a "safe" AI therapy bot? We tested the limits of a new Australian-designed chatbot that's been carefully designed not to hallucinate or be your best friend.

items.title: Today in History, December 30: Beatles star George Harrison stabbed at home
items.summary: Unlike his former bandmate John Lennon, George Harrison survived an attack by a fan, but the musician's friends and family speculated it hastened his death less than two years later.

items.title: Remembering the celebrities and public figures who died in 2025
items.summary: From actors and designers to a Holocaust survivor and a broadcaster, these people made their mark.

items.title: ICC gives MCG pitch 'unsatisfactory' rating as two-day Test fallout continues
items.summary: The ICC has handed down their verdict on the controversial MCG pitch which led to this year's Boxing Day Test wrapping up after just two days.
